1098604022196514817.text: They’ve also simply blocked users from being able to “pin” any content from a number of anti-vaxx and “alternative health” websites. If you try to pin something from stopmandatoryvaccination dot com, or Mercola dot com, you get an error message https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/feb/20/pinterest-anti-vaxx-propaganda-search-facebook?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other …pic.twitter.com/MuCFrHEJBv

1098603436097048576.text: Because the policy is so explicit, Pinterest can use every tool in its arsenal. They have taken down the boards of anti-vaxxers, including “Stop Mandatory Vaccination” and the National Vaccine Information Center, both of which have big followings on FB.https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/feb/20/pinterest-anti-vaxx-propaganda-search-facebook?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other …

1098602524658020354.text: But that’s not the only thing they’ve done. First of all, everything stems from the fact that Pinterest explicitly disallows “anti-vaccine advice”. Neither Facebook nor YouTube have banned this kind of “harmful health misinformation” in their community guidelines.

1098601621293096961.text: Pinterest has acknowledged that the data void for vaccines means that search is basically broken for that term. So they broke their own site to prevent people from falling into the void. https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/feb/20/pinterest-anti-vaxx-propaganda-search-facebook?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other …pic.twitter.com/OLAlQzpy5v

1098611169181515776.text:

1121118028173721600.text: Inaction isn't always because of timidity and confusion inflicted by a ideological fight over deregulation. But I think in this case, it was definitely part of the picture.

1121117675034296320.text: It's not that the FCC for sure didn't have the authority to force STIR/SHAKEN on the industry 5, 6, 7 years ago. But did they actually, though? And do they have it now? I got a lot of conflicting answers while researching this piece.

1121116926384586752.text: Footnote: In 2017, the editorial board called Ajit Pai an "anti-regulation idealogue."https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/29/opinion/sunday/fcc-invokes-internet-freedom-while-trying-to-kill-it.html …

1121116744678924288.text: The long lag in stopping it coincided with a still-ongoing legal fight over how much authority the FCC had over internet protocol-based communications. The agency took several Ls all in a row: Comcast v. FCC 2010; Verizon v. FCC 2014; and then deregulation from within.

1121115177250766848.text: The harms of deregulation in the tech sphere are often hypothetical or hard to see play out in real life. (See, e.g., every hypothetical regarding net neutrality). But the robocall epidemic is very real.

1121114517285425157.text: It's great that is happening! Why didn't it happen years ago?

1121114061540749312.text:
2019: AT&T, Comcast, T-Mobile, Verizon, are all reported to be implementing STIR/SHAKEN, so no regulatory action is taken. 

It is still a matter of debate as to whether the FCC would have had the power to compel the companies to implement STIR/SHAKEN.

1121113650448568320.text: 2018: Ajit Pai demands [with no legal force] that the companies adopt STIR/SHAKEN ffshttps://www.fcc.gov/document/chairman-pai-demands-industry-adopt-protocols-end-illegal-spoofing …

1121113453056237568.text: 2017: Ajit Pai's FCC begins a formal inquiry into a "Call Authentication System"https://www.fcc.gov/document/fcc-seeks-reliable-call-authentication-system …

1121112324272578560.text: 2016: Tom Wheeler asks the telecoms to please adopt STIR/SHAKEN alreadyhttps://www.reuters.com/article/us-wireless-robocalls-idUSKCN10225W …

1121112132357984256.text: The afternoon session of the summit?pic.twitter.com/Vjpa6ShO18

1121111819450368000.text: 2012: The robocall epidemic is in what people believe, at the time, full swing. (They have no idea what's coming a few years down the line). The Federal Trade Commission calls a summithttps://www.ftc.gov/news-events/events-calendar/2012/10/robocalls-all-rage-ftc-summit …

1121111488826003457.text: 2008: IETF officially identifies the problem of spam in SIP communications. (A robocall by any other name would smell as sweet) https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5039

1121111120528285697.text: 2006: IETF puts out "Enhancements for Authenticated Identity Management in the Session Initiation Protocol," which I'm told isn't hugely different from what we now know as SHAKEN/STIR.pic.twitter.com/2vTl5jhkJH

1075142478250930177.text: Never, ever, *ever* talk to me about "don't feed the trolls." You don't know half of what I do to make social media usable, or how hard Twitter, Inc. makes it for me to engage in self-help.
